hints_html:
The linear approximation to a function f(x) centered at the point x = a is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a).\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:
The linear approximation to a function <i>f(x)</i> centered at the point <i>x = a</i> is given by 
:<math>
\displaystyle L(x) = f(a) + f'(a)(x - a).
</math>
question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
Using the formula for linear approximation to a function \(f(x)\) near \(x = a = 8\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} L(x) &= f(a) + f'(a)(x - a) \\ &= \sqrt[3]{8} + \frac{1}{3(8)^{2/3}}(x - 8)\\ &= 2 + \frac{1}{12}(x - 8)\end{aligned}\]

Since 7 is somewhat close to 8, we can estimate \(\sqrt[3]{7}\) by evaluating L(7). Thus,

\[\begin{aligned} L(7) = 2 - \frac{1}{12} = \frac{23}{12} \quad \Rightarrow \quad {\color{blue}\sqrt[3]{7} \approx\frac{23}{12}.}\end{aligned}\]
